question: what is cutaneous larva migrans
definition clm
what is clm
learning: Cutaneous Larva Migrans (CLM) is a skin disease caused by the migration of animal hookworm larvae within the epidermis. It presents as itchy, serpiginous (creeping) skin lesions.
exam:
• Skin disease caused by animal hookworm larvae
• Larvae migrate in epidermis
• Causes creeping eruption

question: causative agent
what causes clm
agent of clm
learning: CLM is caused by larvae of animal hookworms, commonly Ancylostoma braziliense and Ancylostoma caninum, which are parasites of dogs and cats.
exam:
• Ancylostoma braziliense
• Ancylostoma caninum
• Dogs and cats as reservoirs

question: mode of transmission
how is clm transmitted
transmission
learning: Transmission occurs when infective filariform larvae present in contaminated sand or soil penetrate the human skin, usually through barefoot walking or sitting on beaches.
exam:
• Skin penetration by larvae
• Contact with contaminated soil or sand
• Barefoot exposure

question: incubation period
incubation of clm
learning: The incubation period of CLM ranges from 1 to 6 days after the larvae penetrate the skin.

question: clinical features
symptoms of clm
signs of clm
learning: Clinical features include intense itching at the site of penetration, followed by erythematous papules and serpiginous, raised tracks on the skin. Secondary bacterial infection may occur due to scratching.
exam:
• Intense pruritus
• Erythematous papules
• Serpiginous creeping tracks
• Secondary infection

question: common sites
site of infection
where clm occurs
learning: Common sites of infection include the feet, buttocks, thighs, and hands, which are areas frequently in contact with contaminated soil or sand.

question: diagnosis
how to diagnose clm
diagnosis of clm
learning: Diagnosis of CLM is mainly clinical, based on patient history and the characteristic creeping eruption. Skin biopsy may occasionally identify larvae. Differential diagnoses should be considered.
exam:
• Clinical diagnosis
• History of exposure
• Creeping eruption

question: differential diagnosis
differential of clm
learning: Differential diagnoses include herpes zoster, scabies, migratory myiasis, cercarial dermatitis, and onchocerciasis.
exam:
• Herpes zoster
• Scabies
• Migratory myiasis
• Cercarial dermatitis

question: treatment
treatment of clm
how to treat clm
learning: Treatment includes oral albendazole or ivermectin to kill the larvae. Topical or oral antihistamines and corticosteroids help relieve itching. Antibiotics are used if secondary bacterial infection occurs.
exam:
• Albendazole / ivermectin
• Antihistamine
• Corticosteroid
• Antibiotics (secondary infection)

question: prognosis
outcome of clm
learning: CLM is a self-limiting and benign condition. Most cases resolve within 4 to 8 weeks even without treatment, although therapy accelerates recovery.
exam:
• Self-limiting
• Benign condition
• Resolves in 4–8 weeks

question: prevention
prevention of clm
how to prevent clm
learning: Prevention includes regular deworming of pets, controlling stray dogs and cats, avoiding walking barefoot on beaches, and maintaining proper hygiene.
exam:
• Deworm pets
• Control stray animals
• Avoid barefoot exposure
• Hygiene

question: what is toxocariasis
human toxocariasis
learning: Human toxocariasis is a zoonotic infection caused by Toxocara canis or Toxocara cati. Humans are accidental hosts, and larvae migrate to various organs causing inflammatory responses.
exam:
• Zoonotic infection
• Caused by Toxocara canis / cati
• Humans are accidental hosts

question: visceral larva migrans
vlm
learning: Visceral Larva Migrans occurs when Toxocara larvae migrate to organs such as the liver and lungs, causing symptoms like fever, cough, hepatosplenomegaly, and eosinophilia.
exam:
• Larvae migrate to organs
• Liver and lungs involved
• Eosinophilia

question: ocular larva migrans
olm
learning: Ocular Larva Migrans results from larval migration to the eye, leading to visual impairment, retinal granuloma, or even blindness, usually affecting one eye.
exam:
• Eye involvement
• Retinal granuloma
• Visual impairment / blindness

question: neurotoxocariasis
nt
learning: Neurotoxocariasis is a rare condition where larvae migrate to the central nervous system, causing meningitis, encephalitis, or neurological symptoms.
exam:
• CNS involvement
• Meningitis or encephalitis
• Neurological symptoms
